title: Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary vows to slash ticket costs as oil prices drop
text:
6 shares 34
View
comments
Ryanair’s controversial chief executive is predicting good times ahead for passengers who are looking for cheap flights within Europe.
Sticking to a vow he made months ago, Michael O’Leary told travellers to expect the ‘mother and father of all fare wars’ this winter.
He said fares will be slashed in the coming months as passengers reap the rewards of lower oil prices.
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary
Airlines lock in fuel prices on multi-year contracts to protect themselves from volatile cost increases, and with prices near their lowest in six years Mr O’Leary believes the savings will finally be passed on to travellers.
Attending the Ambrosetti Forum, an international economic conference, at Lake Como in Italy, he told CNBC he expects oil prices to remain low in the short- to medium-term.

Mother's anger at Thomson after she claims the holiday... He said: ‘I think it's incumbent certainly on the airline industry, you know, to lock away those kind of cost benefits.
‘As with many European airlines, we intend to pass that onto incredibly low fares this winter. ‘It's one of the reasons that at Ryanair, we're predicting the mother and father of all fare wars this winter.’
Earlier this year, Mr O’Leary told a French newspaper that Dublin-based Ryanair, Europe’s largest budget airline, would slash its fares by as much as 15 per cent over the next two years.
He said the low-cost carrier’s average fare could be as low as €40 (approximately £30) next year. It would be a €6 (approximately £4.50) decrease from Ryanair’s current average ticket price, with Mr O’Leary attributing the anticipated fare cuts to lower oil prices.
This week, Ryanair announced that it had hit another milestone, with a record 10.4 million passengers in August, a 10 per cent increase on the same month last year.
